instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. F7140 was blown so changed it. Getting 8,6V on pin 1 but pin 2 is shorted to ground. I have removed F7140 and injected voltage on pin 2. Nothing is warming. Absolutly nothing.

Checked <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> and seems that PPBUS is shorted to ground through <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL>. Removing <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> short on PPBUS-G3H desappear.


Any advice? Inject voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> and check what is getting warm again?


P.S. Also checked meanwhile <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>/20 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>/630 not seems to be the reason of the short

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
I really don't know how many times need to repeat how, where and when inject voltage.

At least you located the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>.
Unfortunatelly already injected voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; hope started with not too much!!!
Compare that short (only you know exact value), with ohm value to ground at L7310/20, L7430 and L7630.

"Also checked meanwhile <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>/20 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>/630 not seems to be the reason of the short"
Without exact values, we cannot confirm anything.
If you are sure about these, then should be just a cap on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> power rail.
This is also a common fail; usually one of 62uF/11V near CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: I bet one of the caps is shorted 5 volts at 5 amps if the short is not present between VCore and PPBUS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
2informaticos. Thank you again. It was <CAPACITOR>C7373</CAPACITOR>. VIsually it is perfect. Had to remove all caps and return them one by one. 

About injecting. I did it because many people on this forum after facing PPBUS shorted recomend that (Like Duke). Sure i started injecting in 1V and max was 2V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
I'm sure dukefawks never recommended inject voltage before checking high-side MOSFETs.
I learned that from him!!!

If you know all high-side MOSFETs are OK, then is safe to inject even 9V there.
However, ALWAYS start with lower voltage; this way avoid bench power supply to get blocked.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: I've never had issues injecting voltage like that, but I'm sure 2informaticos is correct.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: 2informaticos what is the way to check that high side mosfets are ok? U mean <TRANSISTOR>Q7311</TRANSISTOR>/10/21/20 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>/430 right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
Checkimg exact value D-S for them.
Onboard measuring, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
Drain - Source...
The one with closer ohm value to 000 is shorted.
If none, then you are safe to inject voltage; until 120% of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Don't forget to check all secondary suplies, not only CPU one.
